Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Story: This weekend, my family is holding our annual ancestral ceremony, and my parents have asked me to lead the rituals this year. It’s a big deal—my grandparents will be watching, and everyone expects me to honor our traditions perfectly. I know how much this means to them, and I feel the weight of their expectations pressing on me. Just as I’m rehearsing the prayers, my phone buzzes. It’s Maya, an acquaintance from work. She’s moving to a new apartment and asks if I can help her move some boxes on the same day as the ceremony. She sounds desperate—her usual helpers canceled last minute, and she doesn’t know who else to turn to. I can hear the hope in her voice, and I know she’d do the same for me if our roles were reversed. My mind spins with guilt and anxiety. I want to be the dependable daughter my family needs, but I also don’t want to let Maya down when she’s counting on me. The expectations from both sides pull at me, and I feel trapped, unsure which responsibility should come first.
